content.title: Cardiac Resynchronization Therapy (CRT)
content.summary: Device therapy for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and ventricular dyssynchrony, using biventricular pacing to restore coordinated ventricular contraction and improve cardiac output, symptoms, and survival
key_points: Class I indication: LVEF ≤35%, LBBB ≥150 ms, NYHA II-IV, despite optimal medical therapy
Biventricular pacing resynchronizes left ventricular contraction
CRT-D (with defibrillator) vs CRT-P (pacemaker only) based on sudden death risk
Best response: LBBB morphology, QRS ≥150 ms, female, non-ischemic etiology
30-40% of patients are non-responders - may be due to scar, lead position, or inadequate dyssynchrony
LV lead placed via coronary sinus to pace lateral/posterolateral LV wall
Super-responders: EF normalization, significant reverse remodeling

statement.text: Cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) is a device-based treatment for heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and electrical dyssynchrony. By pacing both ventricles, CRT restores coordinated ventricular contraction, improving cardiac output, reducing mitral regurgitation, and promoting reverse remodeling. Indications include LVEF ≤35%, LBBB with QRS ≥150 ms, and NYHA class II-IV symptoms despite optimal medical therapy. CRT reduces heart failure hospitalizations, improves quality of life, and extends survival.
statement.formal: CRT indication = LVEF ≤35% + QRS ≥150 ms + LBBB + NYHA II-IV on GDMT | Response predictors: LBBB morphology, QRS width, female, non-ischemic

explanation.intuition: In a normal heart, both ventricles contract simultaneously. In heart failure with LBBB, the electrical signal is delayed to the left ventricle, causing the septum and lateral wall to contract out of sync. This dyssynchrony wastes energy and worsens heart failure. CRT adds a pacing lead to the left ventricle that triggers contraction simultaneously with the right ventricle, restoring coordination.
explanation.key_insight: QRS width and morphology are the best predictors of CRT response. LBBB ≥150 ms has the strongest evidence; non-LBBB or narrow QRS rarely benefit. The non-responder problem (30-40%) is often due to extensive scar preventing mechanical improvement despite electrical resynchronization.
explanation.technical_details: CRT requires three leads: right atrial, right ventricular, and left ventricular (coronary sinus). The LV lead is positioned via the coronary sinus into a lateral or posterolateral cardiac vein. Optimal positioning away from scar tissue improves outcomes. Conduction system pacing (His bundle or left bundle branch area pacing) is an emerging alternative.

definitions_glossary.cardiac_resynchronization_therapy: Biventricular pacing to restore coordinated ventricular contraction in heart failure with dyssynchrony
definitions_glossary.biventricular_pacing: Simultaneous pacing of right and left ventricles to synchronize contraction
definitions_glossary.crt_d: CRT with implantable cardioverter-defibrillator for sudden death prevention
definitions_glossary.crt_p: CRT with pacemaker only, without defibrillator capability
definitions_glossary.left_bundle_branch_block: Conduction delay in left bundle causing delayed LV activation and QRS widening ≥120 ms
definitions_glossary.ventricular_dyssynchrony: Uncoordinated ventricular contraction due to electrical conduction delay
definitions_glossary.coronary_sinus: Venous channel on posterior heart used to access left ventricular pacing sites
definitions_glossary.reverse_remodeling: Improvement in LV size and function following CRT
definitions_glossary.non_responder: Patient who does not demonstrate improvement in symptoms or EF after CRT (30-40%)
definitions_glossary.super_responder: Patient with dramatic improvement (EF normalization) after CRT
definitions_glossary.av_delay: Programmed time between atrial and ventricular pacing; optimization improves response
definitions_glossary.vv_delay: Offset timing between right and left ventricular pacing
definitions_glossary.his_bundle_pacing: Alternative pacing strategy targeting the His bundle for physiologic activation
definitions_glossary.lbbap: Left bundle branch area pacing - conduction system pacing alternative to coronary sinus lead

pathophysiology.mechanism: In LBBB, electrical activation of the left ventricle is delayed, causing the septum to contract before the lateral wall. This dyssynchrony reduces stroke volume, increases mitral regurgitation, and wastes energy. CRT paces the LV lateral wall early (simultaneously with or before the RV), restoring synchronous contraction.
physiologic_effects: Improved stroke volume and cardiac output
Reverse remodeling (reduced LV volumes, improved EF)
Improved exercise capacity and quality of life

types_of_dyssynchrony.electrical: QRS widening indicating delayed ventricular activation
types_of_dyssynchrony.mechanical: Delayed contraction of LV segments visible on echo (less predictive)
types_of_dyssynchrony.atrioventricular: Suboptimal timing between atrial and ventricular contraction

strongest_evidence: NYHA class II, III, or ambulatory IV
Optimal guideline-directed medical therapy for ≥3 months

class_iia_indications: High-degree AV block requiring pacing with LVEF ≤35% (CRT preferred over RV pacing)

unfavorable: Atrial fibrillation with inadequate rate control

crt_d.indication: Most patients with CRT indication also qualify for primary prevention ICD
crt_d.considerations: Life expectancy >1 year, absence of comorbidities limiting survival

crt_p.indication: Patients who do not meet ICD criteria or with limited life expectancy
crt_p.examples: NYHA IV not transplant candidate, elderly with significant comorbidities

implantation_procedure.ra_lead: Right atrial appendage for atrial sensing/pacing
implantation_procedure.lv_lead: Coronary sinus to lateral/posterolateral cardiac vein
implantation_procedure.challenges: Coronary sinus anatomy variable; phrenic nerve stimulation; lead stability

optimization.ensure_high_biventricular_pacing: Goal >98% BiV pacing; treat AF, reduce PVCs
optimization.lv_lead_position: Avoid scar; target latest activating segment

definition.@value: Device therapy using biventricular pacing to restore synchronous ventricular contraction in heart failure with reduced ejection fraction and electrical dyssynchrony

skos.scopeNote: Covers indications, patient selection, implantation, optimization, and outcomes; includes CRT-D and CRT-P
skos.example: A 65-year-old woman with non-ischemic cardiomyopathy, LVEF 25%, LBBB with QRS 165 ms, NYHA class III despite optimal medical therapy, undergoes CRT-D implantation; at 6 months, LVEF improved to 40%, NYHA class II

medicalCode.description: Insertion of device in chest, subcutaneous
Insertion of LV pacing electrode for biventricular pacing

learning_objectives: Apply guideline criteria for CRT patient selection
Identify predictors of CRT response and non-response
Distinguish indications for CRT-D vs CRT-P
Describe CRT implantation technique and LV lead positioning
Implement optimization strategies for CRT non-responders
clinical_pearls: LBBB ≥150 ms has Class I indication; non-LBBB rarely benefits
Ensure >98% biventricular pacing - AF and PVCs reduce pacing percentage
30-40% non-response rate - check lead position, optimize AV/VV delays, control AF
Female patients and non-ischemic etiology have better response rates
Scar in the posterolateral wall (LV lead target zone) predicts poor response

board_yield.cardiology_boards: Very High - detailed indications, troubleshooting, emerging techniques

common_misconceptions: All wide QRS patients benefit from CRT (false - LBBB morphology is critical)
Echo dyssynchrony predicts CRT response (false - trials showed it doesn't improve selection)
CRT replaces medical therapy (false - CRT is added to optimized GDMT)

skos:related.skos:note: CRT-D combines CRT with ICD functionality
CRT is part of comprehensive HFrEF management
